questions.question: In a zero trust architecture, which of the following sends information about access requests to another component, then allows/denies requests based on that component's response?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Policy enforcement point

In a zero trust architecture, the policy engine makes policy decisions, and the policy administrator creates/destroys connections (including session-specific credentials, etc.) between subjects and objects based on these decisions. Together, they create the policy decision point.

The policy enforcement point communicates with the policy administrator to send it access requests and receive instructions on whether to approve or deny them.

questions.question: A hardware authenticator generates a new One-Time Password (OTP) for each authentication attempt. This describes which of the following OTP schemes?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: HMAC-based OTP (HOTP)

One-Time Passwords (OTPs) are six to eight digit numbers used as part of a multi-factor authentication scheme. They can be generated in two ways:

  • HMAC-Based One-Time Passwords (HOTP): HOTPs are generated using an incrementing counter. Each authentication attempt using an HOTP causes the authenticator and server to both regenerate it.
  • Time-Based One-Time Password (TOTP): TOTPs are regenerated by the authenticator and the server at regular intervals. With synchronized clocks, this ensures that both devices have the same code at the same time without needing to communicate after initial setup.

Attempt-based OTP (AOTP) and Usage-based OTP (UOTP) are fabricated terms.

questions.question: A vulnerability scanner has generated a list of all known issues with a piece of software. What is the probable source of that list?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: CVE

Common Vulnerability Enumerations (CVEs) list all publicly known vulnerabilities in software and are commonly used by vulnerability scanners.

The Common Vulnerability Scanning System (CVSS) scores the severity of a vulnerability based on Base Score, Temporal Score, and Environmental Score.

Common Weakness Enumerations (CWEs) are maintained by the MITRE Corporation and describe common weaknesses in hardware and software.

The Common Weakness Scoring System (CWSS) uses various factors to create a quantitative score of the severity of a weakness. The three main categories are Base Finding, Attack Surface, and Environmental.

questions.question: Which property of the Biba model prevents writing data to a higher integrity level?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: * (star)

The Biba model is designed to protect integrity. Its three principles are the following:

  • *(star) Integrity Property: Prevents writing data to a higher integrity level.
  • Simple Integrity Property: Prevents reading data at a lower integrity level.
  • Invocation Property: A user can't request read/write access at a higher integrity level.

The Bell-Padula model is designed to protect confidentiality. Its three principles are as follows:

  • Discretionary Security Property/Strong Star Property Rule: A user with read and write access can only perform those actions at the same classification level.
  • Simple Security Rule: Prevents reading data at a higher classification level.
  • *(star)-Property Rule: Prevents writing data to a lower classification level.

questions.question: Which of the following design methodologies drives rapid release cycles by leveraging automation and cross-disciplinary integration?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: DevOps

Developers can use various methodologies to organize software development. Some of the most common include:

  • DevOps: DevOps methodologies use automation to streamline and expedite software development, testing, and deployment. By integrating development, QA, and ops teams and using automation, DevOps enables rapid release cycles.
  • Waterfall: Waterfall moves sequentially through the phases of the SDLC without backtracking or iteration. This approach ensures that each stage is fully completed before the next but is rigid and inflexible.
  • Agile: Agile is a high-level set of principles adopted by many development methodologies, such as eXtreme Programming (XP), Test-Driven Development (TDD), and Scrum. Agile is built around sprints, which make frequent, small changes to software rather than a single, monolithic development cycle.

questions.question: An organization has deployed a network Intrusion Prevention System (IPS) with malware detection capabilities as well as anti-malware on each endpoint. Which of this following BEST describes this approach to security?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Defense in depth

Defense in depth states that an organization should use multiple controls to protect against a potential threat in case one layer of the defenses fails.

Segregation/Separation of Duties (SoD) ensures that no one has full control over a critical process, system, or function. This protects against fraud and single points of failure.

Failing securely means that an application results in a secure, safe state if something goes wrong. This is typically accomplished by implementing error and exception handling mechanisms in the code.

The zero trust principle eliminates implicit trust and requires that every access request be explicitly validated against access controls.

questions.question: Which of the following is a piece of hardware whose unique composition generates a distinct fingerprint?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: PUF

A Physically Unclonable Function (PUF) is a physical component whose unique physical composition is used to generate a digital fingerprint.

A Software Bill Of Materials (SBOM) identifies all the third-party code that went into an application, making it easier to identify potentially vulnerable or malicious components.

A silicon Root Of Trust (ROT) is a tamper-proof hardware component that stores cryptographic keys used for digital signatures and encryption. A silicon ROT is the basis for secure boot.

Service-Level Requirements (SLRs) are part of an agreement between a vendor and customer defining requirements for the software or service provided.

questions.question: An organization is planning its disaster recovery site but has limited budget to create one. Which of the following types of sites might be the BEST fit for the business?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Cold

Recovery sites can be classified based on the level of infrastructure that they provide and the amount of work needed to bring them online. The main types include:

  • Cold: A cold site provides a location and potentially infrastructure (power, internet, etc.) but no devices. It is the cheapest site to maintain but the slowest and most expensive to bring online.
  • Warm: A warm site has more equipment than a cold site, potentially including some devices but needing others to be added when needed.
  • Hot: A hot site is an exact copy of the primary site with the same devices and the same data (potentially with some lag). It’s the most expensive type of site to maintain but the fastest to use.

Some disaster response groups use mobile sites, which build a server room in a shipping container or vehicle that can be easily transported to wherever it is needed.

questions.question: An organization wants to minimize the risk that their software will be deployed in a way that leaves it vulnerable to exploitation. Which of the following principles is MOST applicable here?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Secure defaults

The principle of secure defaults states that default settings should be secure since they are the most likely ones to be used.

Failing securely means that an application results in a secure, safe state if something goes wrong. This is typically accomplished by implementing error and exception handling mechanisms in the code.

The zero trust principle eliminates implicit trust and requires that every access request be explicitly validated against access controls.

The principle of privacy by design states that privacy protections should be built into a system from the very start, not tacked on later.

questions.question: An organization is taking a red-team approach to application testing in which they look for every way that a user might try to break it. This is an example of which of the following types of testing?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Misuse case testing

Code testing is designed to identify software vulnerabilities and can be applied at different stages of the Software Development LifeCycle (SDLC). Some forms of code testing include:

  • Misuse Case Testing: Misuse or abuse case testing identifies ways in which a user could misuse an application and tests its responses to these malicious inputs.
  • Dynamic Application Security Testing (DAST): DAST analyzes a running application for vulnerabilities by providing it with inputs and monitoring their results. DAST can use synthetic inputs, which are scripted interactions with certain expected results, and benchmarks, which evaluate the system against performance, effectiveness, and other metrics.
  • Fuzz Testing: Fuzzing sends various inputs to an application to try to identify failure cases. These inputs may be randomly generated or intelligently selected based on a model of the system to maximize the probability of finding an issue.
  • Interface Testing: Interface testing verifies that the different components of a system will work properly when linked together. The four types of interfaces to test include APIs, User Interfaces (UIs), network interfaces, and physical interfaces.

questions.question: The IPv4 address range 128.0.0.0-191.256.256.256 corresponds to which of the following IPv4 address classes?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Class B

The IPv4 address range 128.0.0.0-191.256.256.256 corresponds to Class B 128-191.

The five classes of IPv4 addresses have first octets in the following ranges:

  • Class A: 0-127
  • Class B: 128-191
  • Class C: 192-223
  • Class D: 224-239
  • Class E: 240-255

questions.question: Which of the following types of physical network segmentation separates data and control traffic onto their own network paths?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Out-of-band

Physical segmentation uses physically separated network components. The three types include:

  • Out-of-band: Data and control traffic are separated onto different paths, and some traffic may have its own, isolated path.
  • Air-gapped: Two networks are physically disconnected from one another, providing the strongest level of segmentation.
  • In-band: This sends both data and control traffic over the same network segment but doesn't actually use physical segmentation.

Multi-band is not a form of physical network segmentation.

questions.question: Which of the following operates primarily at OSI Layer 3?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Router

Routers operate at Layer 3 of the OSI model, working with IP addresses.

Switches primarily operate at OSI Layer 2 but can include VLAN routing capabilities that cross over into Layer 3. 

Hubs are Layer 1 solutions, and bridges are Layer 2.

questions.question: Which of the following stages of the patch management process is LEAST likely to be automated?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Approve Patches

Patches are updates designed to fix vulnerabilities. Approved patches means approving tested patches for deployment in production, potentially via a change management process.

Some of the key steps in a patch management program include:

  • Evaluate Patches: Determine whether the organization needs to deploy the patch.
  • Test Patches: Test patches on a non-production system to ensure that they do their job and don’t create other issues.
  • Approve Patches: Approve tested patches for deployment in production, potentially via a change management process. This stage is the least likely to be automated due to the desire to keep a human in the loop.
  • Deploy Patches: Deploy patches to production systems, potentially using automation.
  • Verify Patch Deployment: Test patches to ensure that they were applied correctly and fix the vulnerability.

questions.question: Which of the following types of contracts might an employee need to sign before being issued a company computer?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: AUP

An Acceptable Use Policy (AUP) describes how an employee is permitted to use company-owned IT assets.

A Service Level Agreement (SLA) is a contract between a service provider and customer defining acceptable, contracted levels of service.

A Non-Disclosure Agreement (NDA) requires someone to protect sensitive company data against exposure to unauthorized parties.

A Non-Compete Agreement (NCA) specifies that a former employee cannot work for a competitor for a certain number of years after leaving the company.

questions.question: Which of the following types of cryptanalytic attacks takes advantage that certain letters are more common in English and other languages than other letters?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Frequency analysis

A frequency analysis attack takes advantage of the relative frequencies of letters to break weak cryptosystems.

A brute-force attack tries every potential private key until the right one is found.

A side-channel attack uses information such as the time it takes to perform cryptographic operations or their electromagnetic emissions to learn about the private key.

A known plaintext takes advantage of knowing both the plaintext and the ciphertext to determine how the cryptosystem works.

questions.question: Printing and IT support are examples of which of the following resources that IAM manages access to?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Services

Identity and Access Management (IAM) is designed to manage access to:

  • Services: An organization may provide various services, such as printing, IT support, and more. Access controls are necessary to manage access to these services.
  • Information: Information is an organization's data, which can be stored on computers, in databases, as paper records, on removable media, or in the cloud. For digitally-stored data, logical access controls are used to manage access.
  • Systems: Systems are devices that provide services to users, such as webservers, file servers, or database servers. Access is controlled based on permissions assigned to accounts.
  • Facilities: Facilities include locations owned or rented by the business, ranging from individual rooms to complete complexes. They are typically protected by physical security controls.
  • Devices: Devices refer to any type of computing system, such as routers, laptops, smartphones, and printers. Corporate data may be stored on personal devices but remains the property of the business.
  • Applications: Applications are software and can be used to access and process corporate data. Permissions can be used to restrict access to applications and the underlying data.

questions.question: Which of the following types of DLP solutions is MOST likely to be used to prevent employees from printing documents containing sensitive data?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Endpoint

Data Loss Prevention (DLP) solutions attempt to block sensitive data from being exfiltrated from an organization’s systems. They can use data labels or look for patterns associated with certain types of sensitive data. DLP systems come in three types:

  • Endpoint: Endpoint DLP solutions can be used to manage sensitive data stored on a system or sent to external devices. For example, an endpoint DLP solution could prevent printing sensitive data or saving it to a USB drive.
  • Network: Network DLP solutions inspect the content of network traffic looking for signs of attempted data exfiltration and preventing it from leaving the network.
  • Cloud DLP: Cloud DLP solutions are network DLP solutions designed to operate in cloud environments.

Mobile is not a form of DLP.

questions.question: Which of the following principles is LEAST related to the others?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Job rotation

Job rotation protects against fraud and builds resiliency by eliminating single points of failure.

Least privilege, need-to-know, and Privileged Account Management (PAM) deal with access control.

questions.question: Which of the following types of intellectual property protections commonly relies on a Non-Disclosure Agreement (NDA)?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Trade secret

Intellectual Property (IP) can be protected in four different ways:

  • Trade secrets: Trade secrets are IP that must be kept secret to be protected. Often, this is accomplished by having employees sign NDAs.
  • Patent: Patents protect inventions against being copied. The subject of a patent must be new, useful, and non-obvious.
  • Copyright: A copyright protects original works against unauthorized distribution, reproduction, and display. Copyrights can cover various things, including text, video, music, and more.
  • Trademark: A trademark protects a word, phrase, image, etc. that is a unique part of a corporate brand.

questions.question: An organization is trying to combat shadow IT and improve security by appointing a point person for security in each business unit. Which of the following BEST describes this technique?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Security champions

A security champions program provides acknowledgement and support of people who take a role advocating for security and educating their colleagues within a team.

Gamification tries to build interest in security training by integrating rewards or penalties, making it more of a game-like experience.

Social engineering is the practice of using manipulation or deception to trick a target into doing what an attacker wants. Phishing is a form of social engineering.

questions.question: Which of the following network topologies offers the GREATEST resiliency to link failures?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Mesh

Mesh topologies directly connect devices to one another via multiple different links. This redundancy makes them highly resilient to link failures.

Ring topologies connect devices in a loop where traffic can only flow one way. The right to send data is managed by a token, which is passed around until it is claimed by a device. In this topology, any link failure breaks the ring, rendering communication impossible.

Bus topologies connect every device to the trunk. Collisions are avoided by listening for traffic, waiting if it is heard, and sending if it hears nothing. In this topology, the bus is a single point of failure.

Star topologies connect every device to a central device (like a switch or router), which manages the traffic. This is a common way of creating network subnets, but the central device is a single point of failure.

questions.question: In SAML, which of the following is the application that a user is trying to access?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Relying Party

The Security Assertion Markup Language (SAML) defines three key parties:

  • Service Provider/Relying Party: Application that the user is trying to access.
  • Principal/User Agent: User trying to access an application.
  • Identity Provider (IdP)/Asserting Party: Third party that manages user authentication and authorization.

questions.question: Which of the following measures the variations in the time between packet arrivals?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Jitter

Latency measures how long it takes a packet to arrive, and jitter is the variation in latency.

Signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) measures how strong a communications signal is compared to background noise.

Bandwidth is the amount of data that can be carried over the network.

questions.question: Which of the following types of SOC audits provides the BEST assessment of an organization's security controls?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: SOC 2 Type II

System and Organization Controls (SOC) audits are performed against a list of requirements defined by the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants (AICPA). A SOC 2 Type II audit is the gold standard for SOC security testing.

SOC audits come in three forms:

  • SOC 1: SOC 1 audits are focused on financial reporting and the controls that an organization has in place that might affect this.
  • SOC 2: SOC 2 audits can be performed against various sets of requirements but always include security testing. These reports are generally intended for an organization’s internal stakeholders and customers.
  • SOC 3: SOC 3 audits are similar to SOC 2, but the results are intended for public disclosure.

SOC audits can also be Type I or Type II. Type I audits provide insight into the organization’s compliance at a particular point in time and are based largely on a documentation review. 

Type II audits are performed over at least six months and provide insight into how sustainable the organization’s program is.

questions.question: RSA is an example of which of the following types of cryptographic algorithms?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Asymmetric

Asymmetric or public key cryptography uses a public key for encryption and a private key for decryption. RSA is an example of an asymmetric algorithm.

Symmetric cryptography uses the same key for encryption and decryption. The Advanced Encryption Standard (AES) is an example of a symmetric algorithm.

Elliptic Curve Cryptography (ECC) is a form of asymmetric cryptography that uses points on an elliptic curve to replace integers in asymmetric encryption algorithms.

Post-quantum encryption algorithms are asymmetric algorithms that are designed to be resistant to quantum computing.

questions.question: Which of the following types of networks places computing power near the devices using it?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Edge

Edge networks place computing power at the network edge, nearer to devices that use it.

Content Distribution Networks (CDNs) cache static web content near users, reducing latency and load on origin servers.

Zigbee is a wireless protocol used by IoT devices.

Egress network is a fabricated term.

questions.question: Which of the following risk responses requires the GREATEST risk appetite?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Acceptance

Possible responses to risk include the following:

  • Acceptance: Accept the potential consequences and costs of the risk to the organization. This requires the greatest risk appetite.
  • Mitigation: Implementing security controls to reduce or eliminate risk.
  • Assignment/Transfer: Transferring responsibility for a risk to someone else, such as an insurer.
  • Avoidance: Avoid taking the action that creates the risk. This can result in lost opportunities.

questions.question: An organization is implementing a zero trust architecture as part of its regulatory compliance strategy. Which of the following forms of network segmentation is the BEST fit for its needs?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Microsegmentation

Microsegmentation divides the network into tiny segments (as small as a single device) to achieve extremely granular control over network traffic. Microsegmentation is essential for a zero-trust security model.

Logical segmentation uses VLANs, VPNs, and other devices to logically divide traffic into isolated networks that are on the same physical network.

Physical segmentation uses physically separated network components. The three types include:

  • Air-gapped: Two networks are physically disconnected from one another, providing the strongest level of segmentation.
  • In-band: This sends both data and control traffic over the same network segment but doesn't actually use physical segmentation.
  • Out-of-band: Data and control traffic are separated onto different paths, and some traffic may have its own, isolated path.

questions.question: Data is commonly protected using a combination of symmetric and asymmetric/public key encryption when in which of the following states?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: In transit

Data can be in one of three states:

  • In Transit: Data in transit is moving over a network, whether internal or external. Often, data in transit is secured using TLS, which uses a combination of symmetric and asymmetric cryptography.
  • At Rest: Data at rest is stored in device memory and is protected by symmetric cryptography.
  • In Use: Data in use is currently being processed by an application. Often, this data is unencrypted, placing it at risk and making it important to clear memory after use. Homomorphic encryption algorithms may be used to protect data in use.

In collection is not a data state.

questions.question: Which of the following is an authentication solution that permits a user to authenticate once and access multiple applications?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: SSO

Single Sign-On (SSO) allows a user to authenticate to the authentication system and access multiple resources using it. The authentication system provides proof of authentication to the applications, allowing them to allow or deny access.

Credential management systems store copies of users’ passwords in an encrypted vault. These can exist within a browser, within the OS, or as a third-party application.

Passwordless authentication uses something you have or something you are factors to authenticate a user’s identity.

Just-In-Time (JIT) provisioning systems automatically create user accounts with a federated application when the user first attempts to access that system. They use the Security Assertion Markup Language (SAML) to transfer the necessary information to the new application.

questions.question: Which of the following Pillars of Information Security is threatened by a DDoS attack?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Availability

Availability refers to a service or data remaining accessible to users. Distributed Denial-of-Service (DDoS) attacks threaten this.

Integrity refers to ensuring that data hasn't been modified by an unauthorized party.

Authenticity refers to ensuring that data was created by its alleged author.

Non-repudiation refers to the inability to deny that someone took a particular action.

questions.question: A SOCKS proxy, which conceals information about the protected network from the other party, is an example of which type of firewall?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Circuit-level

A circuit-level firewall ensures that the TCP handshake was completed and conceals information about the protected network. (Theoretically OSI Layer 5 but also looks at TCP data at Layer 4.) SOCKS proxies are examples of circuit firewalls.

A static packet filtering, screening router, or stateless firewall evaluates each packet independently based on its header fields (OSI Layer 3).

A stateful firewall monitors the current state of network connections and blocks packets that are invalid in context (OSI Layers 3 and 4).

An application-level firewall understands application-specific traffic and can filter traffic accordingly (OSI Layer 7). A Web Application Firewall (WAF) is an example of an application-level firewall.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a self-contained tool that an organization can deploy in its IT infrastructure to enhance network security?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: MDR

Managed Detection and Response (MDR) is a service, not a tool.

MDR, Endpoint Detection and Response (EDR), Endpoint Protection Platforms (EPP), and eXtended Detection and Response (XDR) are all endpoint security solutions. However, EDR, EPP, and XDR are tools.

questions.question: Which of the following converged protocols carries multimedia traffic over the network?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: VoIP

Voice over IP (VoIP) carries voice and multimedia traffic over the network using IP protocols.

Fibre Channel over Ethernet (FCoE) and Internet Small Computer Interface (iSCSI) are for implementing network storage.

InfiniBand over Ethernet (IBoE) runs InfiniBand over Ethernet to support HPC.

questions.question: A user is making a purchase on an ecommerce website and isn't able to see certain information (like shipping fees) until they provide certain information to the site. This is an example of which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Context-Dependent Control

An organization may use various means to manage authorization on a system, including:

  • Context-Dependent Control: Context-dependent control requires the subject to perform certain actions to gain access. For example, when working through a checkout process on an ecommerce page, the user may need to provide certain information before seeing shipping fees.
  • Implicit Deny: The system has a list of authorized users, and anyone not on the list is denied access.
  • Constrained Interface: A constrained interface modifies the user interface based on a subject’s privileges. If a user doesn’t have the right to click a button, then the button is not shown or is grayed-out.
  • Content-Dependent Control: Content-dependent control uses the content within the object to determine how to restrict access. For example, a particular database view might only provide access to certain fields within a table.

questions.question: An organization is renting a system from a cloud provider that offers secure storage of its cryptographic keys. Which of the following does this BEST describe?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: HSM

Trusted Platform Modules (TPMs) are a type of Hardware Security Module (HSM), which includes both built-in and removable devices.

A TPM is a built-in chip on a motherboard used to store cryptographic keys.

Memory protection allocates distinct memory spaces to each running application and prevents them from reading each other's memory.

Public Key Infrastructure (PKI) is a hierarchy of digital certificates used to authenticate public keys for asymmetric cryptography.

questions.question: Where in an audit report should an IT employee look for raw data from the security tools used during the audit?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Appendices

Appendices are raw data from testing tools and any other information needed to back up findings

Audit reports can contain various sections. Some of the key ones include (in order of appearance):

  1. Executive Summary: High-level, non-technical description of key findings.
  2. Methodology: Steps taken during the audit, including information on scope, tools, etc.
  3. Findings: More in-depth discussion of vulnerabilities, defects, etc. Should be organized based on the intended audience (business needs for management, affected systems for IT, etc.).
  4. Recommendations: Actionable advice on how to address the issues described in the Findings section.
  5. Appendices: Raw data from testing tools and any other information needed to back up findings.

questions.question: An organization has stopped making a device but continues to provide updates. Which of the following accurately describes its status?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: After EOL, before EOS

End-Of-life (EOL) is when the organization stops creating software or hardware, while End-Of-Support (EOS) is when they stop providing updates and patches. The device is after EOL but before EOS.

The other answer options are incorrect.

questions.question: Antimalware installed on a device removes a malware infection after it has been identified. This is an example of which of the following types of security controls?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Corrective

The main types of security controls include the following:

  • Corrective: Corrective controls fix issues after a security incident. Antimalware that removes an infection or an auto-close arm on a door are examples of corrective controls.
  • Preventive: Preventive controls are designed to stop an incident from happening. Fences, locks, and access controls are examples of preventive controls.
  • Deterrent: Deterrent controls attempt to discourage an incident from occurring. Corporate policies and security cameras are examples of deterrent controls.
  • Compensating: Compensating controls are used as a replacement when the preferred control is unusable. For example, a company renting an office in a building may put locks on the doors when it can't build a fence.
  • Detective: Detective controls help to identify that an incident is occurring. CCTV, audit trails, and honeypots are examples of detective controls.
  • Recovery: Recovery controls restore normal operations after an incident to a greater extent than corrective ones. Backups and server clusters are examples of recovery controls.

questions.question: Which of the following solutions is designed to enforce corporate policies and access controls?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: CASB

A Cloud Access Security Broker (CASB) sits between users and the cloud and monitors and manages access to cloud resources. CASB is often used to implement access controls or enforce corporate security policies.

Data Loss Prevention (DLP) solutions attempt to block sensitive data from being exfiltrated from an organization’s systems. They can use data labels or look for patterns associated with certain types of sensitive data.

Digital Rights Management (DRM) protects copyrighted works against piracy. This can be accomplished by issuing a license, automatically expiring content, or performing persistent authentication whenever the work is used.

Protected Health Information (PHI) is healthcare data that is collected by healthcare providers and their business associates. It is protected under the Health Insurance Portability and Accessibility Act (HIPAA).

questions.question: An organization is performing an audit where they hire another organization to test their security controls. Which of the following types of audits does this describe?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: External

Audits come in three types:

  • External: External audits are performed by an external organization. Often, they are paid for by the organization, which has a certain level of control over it. However, they are considered more trustworthy than an internal audit since the external auditor is independent of the company under test.
  • Internal: Internal audits are performed by the organization’s own staff and for its purposes. For example, they may be intended to prove that the company is meeting its security goals.
  • Third Party: Third-party audits are controlled and conducted by third parties. A regulator may select or accredit the auditor and can use the results to determine compliance.

Hybrid is not a type of audit.

questions.question: A One-Time Password (OTP) is MOST related to which of the following types of authentication factors?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Something you have

The three main types of authentication factors include:

  • Something You Have: Possession-based factors include smartcards, hardware tokens, smartphones, or a USB drive. A One-Time Password (OTP) is sent to or generated by a physical device, making it a possession-based factor.
  • Something You Know:  Knowledge-based factors include passwords, PINs, passphrases, and security questions.
  • Something You Are: Inherence-based factors include fingerprints, facial recognition, retina and iris scans, palmprints, and voice recognition.

Somewhere you are is a least-used factor that uses IP addresses or geolocation to determine if a login attempt comes from a logical or trusted location.

questions.question: Which of the following parts of the Identity and Access Provisioning Lifecycle is LEAST related to an organization's users?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Service Accounts Management

Service Accounts Management are service accounts that are used by applications instead of users and is the last stage in the  Identity and Access Provisioning Lifecycle.

The Identity and Access Provisioning Lifecycle includes the following stages:

  • Provisioning: Provisioning is the process of creating accounts for a new user. This typically includes enrolling/registering (collecting username and other data about the user), proofing (verifying the identity of the user via photo ID and other means), and establishing the user’s identity by creating required accounts and assigning necessary privileges. Provisioning also may include issuing devices and having users sign off on necessary corporate policies.
  • Deprovisioning: Deprovisioning is the process of offboarding employees and revoking their access to corporate systems. An organization may choose to delete user accounts or simply lock them to ensure that useful data is preserved. It should also collect any company-owned devices from the former employee.
  • Role Definition and Transition: As employees grow and the company changes, new roles may need to be created or assigned. For example, an employee promoted to management will need new access granted to them and some privileges removed. The company may also need to create or update roles to support new types of employees or corporate systems.
  • Account Maintenance: Account maintenance involves reviewing and updating rights and privileges to ensure that they are aligned with a user’s current needs.
  • Account Access Review: Administrators should regularly review accounts to ensure that they have appropriate privileges and are not inactive. Privilege-related issues include excessive privileges (like unneeded administrator-level access) and privilege creep (acquiring and retaining unneeded privileges as job roles change).
  • Privilege Escalation: Privilege escalation involves moving to a higher privilege level via the use of sudo or similar means. This privilege escalation should only occur when needed and be logged.
  • Service Accounts Management: Service accounts are used by applications instead of users. They need certain levels of access, which should be tailored to their role rather than using over-privileged, built-in accounts.

questions.question: An organization has decided to deploy a network firewall in the cloud. Which of the following describes this practice of moving from physical appliances to software-based solutions?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: NFV

Network Function Virtualization (NFV) transforms network functions from physical appliances to software.

Software-Defined Networking (SDN) logically manages the control plane separately from the data plane. Software decides how traffic should be routed over physical links.

Software-Defined WAN (SD-WAN) uses SDN to manage an entire corporate WAN (on-prem, cloud. satellite sites, etc.).

A Virtual SAN (VSAN) merges several network-attached storage devices into a single, virtualized storage container.

questions.question: An organization's applications are developed as microservices, breaking a monolithic application into many functional parts. Which of the following types of testing is ESPECIALLY important for this type of application architecture?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Interface testing

Application vulnerabilities are a common target for cybercriminals. Some ways to manage the number of vulnerabilities that reach production include:

  • Interface Testing: Interface testing verifies that the different components of a system will work properly when linked together. The four types of interfaces to test include APIs, User Interfaces (UIs), network interfaces, and physical interfaces. Microservices, which depend on APIs for communication between their components, especially need interface testing.
  • Code Review: Code review involves another developer reviewing code for potential issues. Often, this is accomplished by requiring a review before code is incorporated into a code repository.
  • Fuzz Testing: Fuzzing sends various inputs to an application to try to identify failure cases. These inputs may be randomly generated or intelligently selected based on a model of the system to maximize the probability of finding an issue.
  • Misuse Case Testing: Misuse or abuse case testing identifies ways in which a user could misuse an application and tests its responses to these malicious inputs.

questions.question: Which of the following combinations of factors does NOT make a valid combination for MFA?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: OTP and smartcard

One-Time Passwords (OTPs) and smartcards are both examples of possession-based factors. Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) requires two factors of different types, which the other answers have:

  • Facial recognition (something you are) and OTP (something you have)
  • Facial recognition (something you are) and PIN (something you know)
  • Password (something you know) and OTP (something you have)

questions.question: Which of the following stages of the Identity and Access Provisioning Lifecycle involves verifying the user's identity?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Provisioning

The Identity and Access Provisioning Lifecycle includes the following stages:

  • Provisioning: Provisioning is the process of creating accounts for a new user. This typically includes enrollment/registration (collecting username and other data about the user), proofing (verifying the identity of the user via photo ID and other means), and establishing the user’s identity by creating required accounts and assigning necessary privileges. Provisioning also may include issuing devices and having users sign off on necessary corporate policies.
  • Role Definition and Transition: As employees grow and the company changes, new roles may need to be created or assigned. For example, an employee promoted to management will need new access granted to them and some privileges removed. The company may also need to create or update roles to support new types of employees or corporate systems.
  • Account Maintenance: Account maintenance involves reviewing and updating rights and privileges to ensure that they are aligned with a user’s current needs.
  • Account Access Review: Administrators should regularly review accounts to ensure that they have appropriate privileges and are not inactive. Privilege-related issues include excessive privileges (like unneeded administrator-level access) and privilege creep (acquiring and retaining unneeded privileges as job roles change).
  • Deprovisioning: Deprovisioning is the process of offboarding employees and revoking their access to corporate systems. An organization may choose to delete user accounts or simply lock them to ensure that useful data is preserved. It should also collect any company-owned devices from the former employee.
  • Privilege Escalation: Privilege escalation involves moving to a higher privilege level via the use of sudo or similar means. This privilege escalation should only occur when needed and be logged.
  • Service Accounts Management: Service accounts are used by applications instead of users. They need certain levels of access, which should be tailored to their role rather than using over-privileged, built-in accounts.

questions.question: Which of the following describes a NAC solution that performs ongoing monitoring of a device throughout its session via software installed on that device?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Postadmission agent-based

Agent-based NACs install agent software on a device to monitor its security posture and compliance with corporate policies, while agentless NACs monitor the network as a whole.

Postadmission monitors user behavior and applies access controls accordingly.

Preadmission permits or denies access to the network based on compliance with corporate policy (installed AV, patching, etc.).

questions.question: An organization labels all removable media with classification markings to help protect against potential data leaks. This is an example of which of the following types of security controls?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Deterrent

The main types of security controls include the following:

  • Deterrent: Deterrent controls attempt to discourage an incident from occurring. Labeling removable media can be a deterrent control since it helps to prevent mistakes.
  • Corrective: Corrective controls fix issues after a security incident. Antimalware that removes an infection or an auto-close arm on a door are examples of corrective controls.
  • Preventive: Preventive controls are designed to stop an incident from happening. Fences, locks, and access controls are examples of preventive controls.
  • Detective: Detective controls help to identify that an incident is occurring. CCTV, audit trails, and honeypots are examples of detective controls.

questions.question: A government employee has a Top Secret clearance with access to documents labeled Melon. Which of the following access control systems is in use?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Mandatory access control

Access control can be managed under several different models, including:

  • Mandatory Access Control (MAC): MAC assigns classification labels to subjects and objects that are used to govern access. The Unclassified, Confidential, Secret, and Top Secret system with compartments within each used by some governments is an example of MAC.
  • Attribute-Based Access Control (ABAC): ABAC defines and assigns various attributes to users, and access to resources is governed based on combinations of attributes. For example, an IT manager may have attributes granting them access to IT resources and management-level resources.
  • Discretionary Access Control (DAC): DAC allows the owner of an asset to manage access to that asset via an ACL. This is the default access control model used by most operating systems.
  • Role-Based Access Control (RBAC): RBAC defines groups based on various roles and assigns privileges to these groups. Users are assigned to a group and inherit the privileges associated with it. Group Policies in Windows use RBAC. RBAC is good for protecting against privilege creep because removing a user from a group removes all the associated permissions.

questions.question: Which of the following solutions is designed to protect against software piracy?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: DRM

Digital Rights Management (DRM) protects copyrighted works against piracy. This can be accomplished by issuing a license, automatically expiring content, or performing persistent authentication whenever the work is used.

A Cloud Access Security Broker (CASB) sits between users and the cloud and monitors and manages access to cloud resources. CASB is often used to implement access controls or enforce corporate security policies.

Data Loss Prevention (DLP) solutions attempt to block sensitive data from being exfiltrated from an organization’s systems. They can use data labels or look for patterns associated with certain types of sensitive data.

Personally Identifiable Information (PII) can be used to uniquely identify someone. Examples include names, social security numbers, date of birth, etc.

questions.question: Which of the following secure protocols is designed to provide remote access to the system terminal?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: SSH

The Secure SHell (SSH) provides secure remote access to the system terminal.

Secure Sockets Layer/Transport Layer Security (SSL/TLS) encapsulates protocols such as HTTP, offering encryption and authentication

IPsec is a VPN protocol built using TCP/IP protocols.

questions.question: Fuzzing is MOST related to which of the following types of software testing?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: DAST

Organizations can use various forms of testing to identify flaws in application code, including:

  • Dynamic Application Security Testing (DAST): DAST analyzes a running application for vulnerabilities by providing it with inputs and monitoring their results. Fuzzing is a type of DAST.
  • Static Application Security Testing (SAST): SAST often inspects the source code of the application to identify common flaws in the code. It can be applied early in the SDLC because it doesn’t require a completed, runnable application.
  • Interactive Application Security Testing (IAST): IAST combines internal visibility into an application with dynamic testing to enhance vulnerability detection.
  • Software Composition Analysis (SCA): SCA identifies vulnerabilities inherited from third-party libraries and dependencies, protecting against supply chain vulnerabilities.

questions.question: An organization is using a threat modeling framework that explicitly considers how difficult a vulnerability is to find and exploit. Which of the following frameworks is it MOST likely using?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: DREAD

DREAD classifies threats based on the Damage, Reproducibility, Exploitability, Affected users, and Discoverability of a threat.

STRIDE is a Microsoft-developed threat modeling framework named for the six types of threats that an attacker may pose to the organization.

PASTA is a seven-step threat modeling framework that considers both risks and the importance of various corporate assets.

VAST is a threat modeling framework customized for Agile environments.

questions.question: Which of the following authentication systems includes a Ticket-Granting Service (TGS) and an Authentication Service (AS)?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Kerberos

Kerberos is an authentication system commonly used to implement SSO on internal networks.

RADIUS and TACACS+ are remote access protocols for corporate networks.

SAML is a standard commonly used to implement SSO systems.

questions.question: Which of the following teams includes both offensive and defensive specialists?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Purple

A cybersecurity exercise may include a few types of teams:

  • Purple Team: A cross-disciplinary team combining red and blue team members. This could involve a team playing both roles, members switching between the teams during the exercise, or a retrospective where the red and blue teams share findings.
  • Red Team: Offensive security experts attacking the organization’s systems.
  • Blue Team: Defenders who configure the organization’s security and actively protect it during the exercise.
  • White Team: An impartial team that monitors and judges the exercise.

questions.question: Which of the following accurately shows the encapsulation of an HTTP packet from the application to the physical layer?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: HTTP/TCP/IP/Ethernet

HTTP/TCP/IP/Ethernet correctly shows the encapsulation of an HTTP packet from the application to the physical layer. HTTP doesn't include the TLS layer, which would make it HTTPS.

questions.question: HIPAA explicitly protects which of the following types of data?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: PHI

Protected Health Information (PHI) is healthcare data that is collected by healthcare providers and their business associates. It is protected under the Health Insurance Portability and Accessibility Act (HIPAA).

Personally Identifiable Information (PII) can be used to uniquely identify someone. Examples include names, social security numbers, date of birth, etc.

Proprietary data includes an organization’s Intellectual Property (IP) and similar information that can help it compete in the marketplace.

Data Loss Prevention (DLP) solutions attempt to block sensitive data from being exfiltrated from an organization’s systems.

questions.question: An IDS or antimalware solution is MOST applicable to which stage of the incident management lifecycle?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Detection

The incident management lifecycle includes the following steps:

  • Detection: Identify the intrusion using an IDS, antimalware, or other means.
  • Response: Control transfers to the Incident Response Team (IRT), who is responsible for investigating, mitigating, and recovering from the incident.
  • Mitigation: The IRT contains the incident, potentially by disconnecting an infected computer, disabling a compromised account, or similar actions.
  • Remediation: The security team performs Root Cause Analysis (RCA) to identify and address the initial vulnerability that allowed the incident to occur.
  • Reporting: Information about the incident is reported to internal stakeholders, regulators, customers, or law enforcement.
  • Recovery: Affected systems are restored to a normal state via a reboot, restoration from backups, or complete rebuild.
  • Lessons Learned: The IRT performs a retrospective to identify potential inefficiencies or errors in their response that could be corrected for future incidents.

questions.question: Which of the following requirements for forensic evidence doesn't require interpretation or rely on hunches?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Objective

Evidence that stands alone and doesn’t rely on interpretation or hunches is objective.

Evidence collected as part of a digital forensics process should be the following:

  • Accurate: The evidence should be free from errors, conflicts with other evidence, or integrity issues.
  • Convincing: The evidence provides a strong argument that a user performed a particular action.
  • Admissible: The evidence fulfills rules for evidence, such as legal collection, relevance, and reliability.
  • Authenticity: The evidence should have a clear chain of custody back to an undisputed origin.
  • Comprehensibility: The evidence should be understandable to non-technical personnel or have expert witnesses available.
  • Objective: The evidence stands alone and doesn’t rely on interpretation or hunches.

questions.question: In a cybersecurity exercise, which of the following imitates a cyber threat actor targeting the organization?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Red team

A cybersecurity exercise may include a few types of teams:

  • Red Team: Offensive security experts attacking the organization’s systems. They imitate an attacker identifying and exploiting vulnerabilities.
  • Blue Team: Defenders who configure the organization’s security and actively protect it during the exercise.
  • White Team: An impartial team that monitors and judges the exercise.
  • Purple Team: A cross-disciplinary team combining red and blue team members. This could involve a team playing both roles, members switching between the teams during the exercise, or a retrospective where the red and blue teams share findings.

questions.question: An organization has calculated its ALE as $5,000 for an asset with an AV of $10,000 and an EV of 0.05. What is the ARO?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: 10

The Annualized Loss Expectancy (ALE) is calculated as the product of its Annualized Rate of Occurrence (ARO) and its Single Loss Expectancy (SLE). The SLE is the product of the Asset's Value (AV) and the percentage of that value lost due to an incident or the Exposure Factor (EV).

With an ALE of $5,000, AV of $10,000, and EV of 0.05:

$5000 = ARO x ($10,000 x 0.05) = ARO x $500

ARO = 10

questions.question: Which of the following stages of the Capability Maturity Model Integration (CMMI) demonstrates the LOWEST level of maturity?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Managed

The Capability Maturity Model Integration (CMMI) was developed by the U.S. Department of Defense and Carnegie Mellon University’s Software Engineering Institute (SEI). Managed is the second stage.

CMMI defines five maturity stages in the following order:

  1. Initial: Processes are ad hoc, reactive, and unpredictable.
  2. Managed: Processes are still largely reactive but are characterized or documented for an individual project.
  3. Defined: Proactive processes are defined and documented at the organizational level rather than the project level.
  4. Quantitatively Managed: The organization tracks quantitative metrics regarding processes.
  5. Optimizing: The organization has a culture of continuous improvement where processes are documented, measured, and improved through lessons learned.

questions.question: During which stage of the incident management lifecycle does the IRT perform a Root Cause Analysis (RCA)?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Remediation

During the remediation stage, the security team performs Root Cause Analysis (RCA) to identify and address the initial vulnerability that allowed the incident to occur.

The incident management lifecycle includes the following steps:

  1. Detection: Identify the intrusion using an IDS, antimalware, or other means.
  2. Response: Control transfers to the Incident Response Team (IRT), who is responsible for investigating, mitigating, and recovering from the incident.
  3. Mitigation: The IRT contains the incident, potentially by disconnecting an infected computer, disabling a compromised account, or similar actions.
  4. Reporting: Information about the incident is reported to internal stakeholders, regulators, customers, or law enforcement.
  5. Recovery: Affected systems are restored to a normal state via a reboot, restoration from backups, or complete rebuild.
  6. Remediation: The security team performs an RCA to identify and address the initial vulnerability that allowed the incident to occur.
  7. Lessons Learned: The IRT performs a retrospective to identify potential inefficiencies or errors in their response that could be corrected for future incidents.

questions.question: An employee may receive special training on the use of VPNs as part of a corporate policy to prepare them for which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Travel

An organization may have a few different mechanisms in place to balance personnel safety and security, including:

  • Travel: Employees on travel might be targeted by criminals. Travelers should be careful who they open the door to, not carry devices with sensitive data, use a VPN on untrusted networks (like hotel Wi-Fi), and be aware of the risk of malware or listening devices being installed on devices left in hotel rooms.
  • Duress: An organization may have an alarm that sends a distress signal to law enforcement or security paired with a code phrase that indicates whether the signal was real or an accident. Electronic locks can also have multiple codes, one of which is configured to send a distress signal if used.
  • Emergency Management: Emergency management plans help ensure personnel safety during a disaster. For example, an organization should have evacuation plans and fire doors if a fire occurs.

Incident responders may use a VPN, but it's not usually essential to their role.

questions.question: Which of the following forms of authorization management involves mapping out all the things that a particular subject is permitted to do?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Capability List

An organization may use various means to manage authorization on a system, including:

  • Capability List: Capability lists are like Access Control Lists (ACLs) focused on a subject, describing all the things that they are permitted to do.
  • Implicit Deny: The system has a list of authorized users, and anyone not on the list is denied access.
  • Access Control Matrix: Access control matrices map combinations of subjects and objects to their associated permissions, rights, and privileges. An Access Control List (ACL) is a row in this matrix associated with a single object.
  • Constrained Interface: A constrained interface modifies the user interface based on a subject’s privileges. If a user doesn’t have the right to click a button, then the button is not shown or is grayed-out.

questions.question: Which of the following comes LATEST in the information system lifecycle?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Deployment

Transition/deployment is the latest stage among the answer options given.

The information system lifecycle includes the following stages:

  1. Stakeholders needs and requirements
  2. Requirements analysis
  3. Architectural design
  4. Development /implementation
  5. Integration
  6. Verification and validation
  7. Transition/deployment
  8. Operations and maintenance/sustainment
  9. Retirement/disposal

questions.question: Which of the following documents is MOST likely to exist between an organization and a cloud service provider?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: SLA

A Service Level Agreement (SLA) is a contract between a service provider and customer defining acceptable, contracted levels of service.

A Non-Disclosure Agreement (NDA) requires someone to protect sensitive company data against exposure to unauthorized parties.

An Acceptable Use Policy (AUP) describes how an employee is permitted to use company-owned IT assets.

A Non-Compete Agreement (NCA) specifies that a former employee cannot work for a competitor for a certain number of years after leaving the company.

questions.question: Which of the following stages of patch deployment comes the EARLIEST?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Test Patches

Test patches comes in the early stages of patch deployment.

Patches are updates designed to fix vulnerabilities. Some of the key steps in a patch management program include:

  1. Evaluate Patches: Determine whether the organization needs to deploy the patch.
  2. Test Patches: Test patches on a non-production system to ensure that they do their job and don’t create other issues.
  3. Approve Patches: Approve tested patches for deployment in production, potentially via a change management process.
  4. Deploy Patches: Deploy patches to production systems, potentially using automation.
  5. Verify Patch Deployment: Test patches to ensure that they were applied correctly and fix the vulnerability.

questions.question: Which of the following architectures transfers responsibility for managing an application's execution environment (storage, compute, networking, etc.) to a third party?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Serverless

Serverless architectures allow applications to run in an environment totally managed by the service provider. This relieves the developer of the responsibility of managing compute, storage, networking, etc.

Microservices break an application into different functional parts, which communicate via Application Programming Interfaces (APIs). These tend to be easier to deploy and scale than traditional applications but are harder to monitor.

Containerization places an application within a sandboxed environment containing all its dependencies. This enables containerized applications to be deployed anywhere regardless of the underlying infrastructure.

Embedded systems build specialized applications into single-purpose hardware. Often, embedded systems are used to interact with the physical world.

questions.question: An employee has access to three sets of resources because they are in IT, a manager, and an IT manager. Which of the following access control models does this BEST describe?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Attribute-based access control

Access control can be managed under several different models, including:

  • Attribute-Based Access Control (ABAC): ABAC defines and assigns various attributes to users, and access to resources is governed based on combinations of attributes. For example, an IT manager may have attributes granting them access to IT resources and management-level resources.
  • Discretionary Access Control (DAC): DAC allows the owner of an asset to manage access to that asset via an ACL. This is the default access control model used by most operating systems.
  • Role-Based Access Control (RBAC): RBAC defines groups based on various roles and assigns privileges to these groups. Users are assigned to a group and inherit the privileges associated with it. Group Policies in Windows use RBAC. RBAC is good for protecting against privilege creep because removing a user from a group removes all the associated permissions.
  • Mandatory Access Control (MAC): MAC assigns classification labels to subjects and objects that are used to govern access. The Unclassified, Confidential, Secret, and Top Secret system with compartments within each used by some governments is an example of MAC.

questions.question: Which of the following is MOST related to a grant of read/write access to a file?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Permission

Some key terms in IAM include:

  • Permissions: Permissions define what a user is permitted to do with a particular object, such as read/write access for a file.
  • Right: Rights define the ability to take a particular action on an object.
  • Privilege: Privilege combines rights and elevated permissions. An administrator-level account has elevated permissions and the right to act on almost any object on a computer.

An attribute is something that describes a subject or object.

questions.question: Which of the following methods of data deletion is MOST effective for a Solid-State Drive (SSD)?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Purging

Data remanence refers to information that remains after a disk, USB drive, etc. has been erased. Simply deleting a file isn’t enough since additional information will be left behind. Some methods of securely deleting data include:

  • Purging: Purging repeats the clearing process multiple times to completely remove all data. However, this isn’t always trusted and is not a method approved by the U.S. government for clearing Top Secret media.
  • Erasing: Erasing uses the built-in delete functionality on a computer to remove pointers to the data. However, the actual data remains on disk until it is overwritten by something else.
  • Clearing: Clearing overwrites data with other data. Depending on the number of passes, the storage medium, and data written, data may be retrievable using specialized technology.
  • Degaussing: Degaussing uses a magnetic field to wipe data from magnetic tapes and Hard Disk Drives (HDDs). It doesn’t work on optical disks or flash storage (including USBs, SSDs, and SD cards).

Since erasing never works, degaussing doesn't work on SSDs, and purging is a stronger form of clearing, purging is the best available option.

questions.question: Which of the following is a commonly used tool for measuring the severity of an exploitable flaw in a piece of software?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: CVSS

The Common Vulnerability Scanning System (CVSS) scores the severity of a vulnerability based on Base Score, Temporal Score, and Environmental Score.

The Common Weakness Scoring System (CWSS) uses various factors to create a quantitative score of the severity of a weakness. The three main categories are Base Finding, Attack Surface, and Environmental.

Common Weakness Enumerations (CWEs) are maintained by the MITRE Corporation and describe common weaknesses in hardware and software.

Common Vulnerability Enumerations (CVEs) list all publicly known vulnerabilities in software and are commonly used by vulnerability scanners.

questions.question: An organization suspects that an employee account has been compromised by an attacker. Which of the following is MOST suited to determining this?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: UEBA

User and Entity Behavioral Analytics (UEBA) looks for anomalous user actions that could be indicative of a compromised account or malicious activity.

Continuous monitoring is intended to ensure that an organization's security controls are effective between audits.

Egress monitoring looks for attempted exfiltration of corporate data.

Threat hunting searches for signs of an intruder resident within an organization's network.

questions.question: For which of the following types of software are vulnerabilities typically well-known, making them a prime target for cybercriminals?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Commercial-off-the-shelf

Companies can acquire software from various sources, including:

  • Commercial-off-the-shelf (COTS): COTS software like Microsoft Word is purchased by the organization to run on its own infrastructure. COTS vulnerabilities are often well-known, and a lack of access to source code makes vulnerabilities difficult to detect.
  • Open Source Software (OSS): OSS is made freely available for anyone to use and includes access to the source code of the application. OSS often assumes that vulnerabilities will be detected because there are many eyes on it. Also, there is the risk that vulnerable or malicious code may be inserted into the project.
  • Third Party: Third-party software is developed by an external organization under contract. The development process may be managed by SLAs, and the company may or may not have access to source code.
  • Cloud Services: Cloud services like Software as a Service (SaaS), Infrastructure as a Service (IaaS), and Platform as a Service (PaaS) have varying breakdowns of responsibility between the cloud customer and provider. In SaaS, the organization uses an application created and managed by the cloud provider.

questions.question: Which of the following data roles is MOST likely to reside within an organization's IT/security department?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Data custodian

A data custodian handles day-to-day protection and management of data, a role delegated to them by the data owner. Data custodians are usually within the IT/security department

A data owner is ultimately responsible for data and controls its classification, labeling, and disclosure. This is often the CEO or other senior management.

A data controller is responsible for defining how different types of data are collected and processed. Data controllers are also often senior management.

A data processor performs the actual processing of data, a role delegated to them by the data controller. Data processors are employees within the department who use the collected data.

questions.question: At which layer of the OSI model do protocols such as TCP and UDP operate?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Layer 4

Transmission Control Protocol (TCP) and User Datagram Protocol (UDP) operate at Layer 4 (the Transport Layer) of the Open Systems Interconnection (OSI) model. The Transport Layer is responsible for end-to-end communication, flow control, and error handling between devices.

Ethernet operates at Layer 2 (the Data Link Layer), managing physical addressing through MAC (Media Access Control) addresses.

Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) operates at Layer 3 (the Network Layer) because it is primarily used for network diagnostics and error reporting rather than managing end-to-end communication like TCP and UDP. Internet Protocol (IP) also functions at Layer 3, handling logical addressing and routing.

Layer 5 (the Session Layer) is responsible for session management and includes protocols such as WinSock and RPC (Remote Procedure Call).

questions.question: Which of the following is part of the CIA Triad?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Availability

The CIA triad is Confidentiality, Integrity, and Availability. Availability refers to the ability of users to access data or systems.

Authenticity is one of the 5 Pillars of Information Security but not the CIA triad.

Admissibility relates to digital evidence in a court of law.

Accessibility is not a term used in the CISSP.

questions.question: Which section of an audit report should assume little or no technical background?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Executive summary

Audit reports can contain various sections. Some of the key ones include:

  • Executive Summary: High-level, non-technical description of key findings.
  • Methodology: Steps taken during the audit, including information on scope, tools, etc.
  • Findings: More in-depth discussion of vulnerabilities, defects, etc. Should be organized based on the intended audience (business needs for management, affected systems for IT, etc.).
  • Recommendations: Actionable advice on how to address the issues described in the Findings section.
  • Appendices: Raw data from testing tools and any other information needed to back up findings.

questions.question: Which of the following does NOT limit an employee's knowledge of potentially sensitive functions within the company?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Job rotation

Job rotation moves employees through different roles within the company. This can help identify potential errors, deter fraud, and reduce single points of failure since many people can do any job. It also means that an employee knows a great deal about how the company works that isn't required for their current role.

Need-to-know grants access to sensitive information only if a user needs it to perform their role.

Least privilege limits access and rights to only those that a user needs to do their job. It goes beyond need-to-know to include ability to access systems, modify data, etc.

Separation/segregation of Duties (SoD) breaks critical duties, functions, or systems across multiple personnel. This protects against fraud, requiring the users to collude to defraud the company.

questions.question: Which of the following is the MOST PROACTIVE method of managing an organization's security and risk exposure?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Training and Awareness

Security management processes should include the following:

  • Training and Awareness: Cybersecurity awareness training ensures that employees are aware of potential security threats and best practices. Training should be performed regularly and be tailored to a user’s role and the threats that they are most likely to face. Training and awareness is highly proactive since it attempts to prevent actions that would leave the organization vulnerable to attack.
  • Log Reviews: Log reviews can be used to identify anomalous behavior by an application or potential security incidents. For example, reviewing access logs can help to identify anomalous access attempts or abuse of legitimate privileges.
  • Account Management: Account reviews are performed to ensure that accounts do not have excessive permissions, accounts of terminated users are deleted/locked, and potentially checking the actions performed by a user. These may be performed only for privileged accounts or a randomly sampled set of accounts.
  • Business Continuity and Disaster Recovery (BC/DR): BC/DR programs should include strategies for maintaining operations during an incident (BC) and restoring normal operations after the incident (DR). Backups, redundant systems, and other controls are key parts of BC/DR programs, and their effectiveness should be regularly reviewed.

questions.question: Which of the following types of security testing simulates an attack by someone with the knowledge of a system administrator?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: White-box

Penetration tests can be classified based on the level of information provided to the tester, including:

  • White-Box: White-box tests give the tester full access to documentation about the environment being assessed. These tests are generally the fastest and cheapest to perform because they eliminate the need for reconnaissance.
  • Black-Box: In a black-box test, the tester is provided no information about the environment under test. This simulates an attack by an external attacker with no knowledge of the target environment.
  • Gray-Box: Gray-box testing provides the tester with limited information about the test environment. Often, this is designed to simulate an attack by an average user and provides a balance between the accuracy of a black-box test and the cost/speed of a white-box test.

Red-box is not a type of test.

questions.question: After performing a risk assessment, an organization has decided not to perform a merger with another organization. This describes which of the following responses to risk?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Avoidance

Possible responses to risk include the following:

  • Avoidance: Avoid taking the action that creates the risk. This can result in lost opportunities.
  • Mitigation: Implementing security controls to reduce or eliminate risk.
  • Assignment/Transfer: Transferring responsibility for a risk to someone else, such as an insurer.
  • Acceptance: Accept the potential consequences and costs of the risk to the organization.

questions.question: Which of the following is a technology that optimizes network traffic routing between geographically distributed sites?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: SD-WAN

Software-Defined WAN (SD-WAN) uses SDN to manage an entire corporate WAN (on-prem, cloud. satellite sites, etc.) and optimally route traffic between different sites.

Software-Defined Networking (SDN) logically manages the control plane separately from the data plane. Software decides how traffic should be routed over physical links.

Network Function Virtualization (NFV) transforms network functions from physical appliances to software.

A Virtual SAN (VSAN) merges several network-attached storage devices into a single, virtualized storage container.

questions.question: Which of the following parts of an automated CI/CD pipeline deals with merging code into GitHub repos?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Continuous integration

Continuous Integration (CI) continually merges new code into a code repository, such as GitHub. This may include manual code reviews or automated testing before acceptance.

Continuous Delivery (CD) builds a release candidate of an application and moves it to a non-production environment. From there, it can be tested and manually deployed to a live environment.

Continuous deployment automatically performs testing and deploys software to a production environment. This is faster and more efficient but requires a range of automated tests to ensure that nothing breaks.

Continuous development is not a part of a CI/CD pipeline.

questions.question: Which of the following types of investigations requires proving something "beyond a reasonable doubt," forcing strict evidence collection?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Criminal

Security investigations fall into one of four types:

  • Criminal: Criminal investigations involve law enforcement, must follow strict evidence collection requirements, and are intended to prove a crime "beyond a reasonable doubt."
  • Administrative: Administrative investigations are internal affairs and may be intended to troubleshoot a problem or address an HR issue. Operational (troubleshooting) investigations have the loosest standards, while ones conducted for HR purposes may have a higher requirement for proof.
  • Civil Investigations: Civil investigations do not involve law enforcement and may be conducted internally or with external consultants. They are conducted to collect evidence to bring charges in civil court. They have less stringent evidence standards than criminal investigations because they only have to prove that the "preponderance of the evidence" supports the case.
  • Regulatory: Regulatory investigations are conducted by regulators to prove non-compliance with laws and standards. Their requirements depend on the type of case to be brought against a non-compliant company.

questions.question: A company is developing software that will be hold EU citizen data and be subject to GDPR. Which of the following principles is MOST applicable to this situation?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Privacy by design

The principle of privacy by design states that privacy protections should be built into a system from the very start, not tacked on later. This is especially relevant in this scenario, as GDPR is a data privacy law designed to protect EU citizens' data.
