The principle of secure defaults states that default settings should be secure since they are the most likely ones to be used.

Failing securely means that an application results in a secure, safe state if something goes wrong. This is typically accomplished by implementing error and exception handling mechanisms in the code.

The zero trust principle eliminates implicit trust and requires that every access request be explicitly validated against access controls.

questions.question: An organization is increasingly adopting SaaS solutions. Which of the following forms of Federated Identity Management (FIM) may they need to adopt?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Hybrid

Federated Identity Management (FIM) enables a user to use the same identity across multiple organizations, enabling SSO across them. The user authenticates to their own organization’s systems, which share authentication information with the other, federated organizations. 

FIMs come in three types:

  • Hybrid: Hybrid FIM combines on-prem and cloud-based federation. This may federate an organization’s on-prem IAM solution with a cloud-based one used to access SaaS applications.
  • On-Prem: On-prem federated identity manages identities across different systems within an organization. For example, after a merger or acquisition, a company may implement federation between the two organization’s systems to enable SSO without rebuilding its IAM system.
  • Cloud-Based: Cloud-based federated identity uses a third-party provider to implement federated identity. Many companies, such as Google, Microsoft, and Meta, offer SSO and federated identity.

Universal is not a form of FIM.

questions.question: An application uses input validation to ensure that user-provided inputs are correct before processing them. Which of the following aspects of test coverage would be MOST relevant to this section of the code?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Condition coverage

Test coverage analysis is designed to estimate the percentage of potential use cases that have been explicitly tested for a piece of software. Five common criteria for this include:

  • Condition Coverage: Verifying that logical tests have been checked against each type of input. The test cases used for input validation are conditional statements that should be fully tested.
  • Branch Coverage: Testing all conditions of every if/else statement.
  • Loop Coverage: Running every loop 0, 1, and multiple times.
  • Statement Coverage: Executing every line of code within the application.
  • Function Coverage: Testing every function in the code and the results it returns.

questions.question: Which of the following types of disaster response plan testing has the GREATEST potential impact on business operations?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Full-Interruption

A full-interruption test switches operations over from the primary to the recovery site. 

Testing disaster response plans is essential to ensure that they are effective and nothing is missed. Testing can be performed in various ways, including:

  • Full-Interruption Test: A full-interruption test actually switches operations over from the primary to the recovery site. This is more disruptive and risky than a parallel test but actually verifies that the organization’s failover processes work.
  • Walkthrough: In a walkthrough, the team physically performs the actions described in the plan (unless they would disrupt operations). This can build familiarity and help identify parts of the plan that are impossible or require additional resources.
  • Simulation: In a simulation like a fire drill, the team is given a scenario and tasked with responding to it. This is more realistic than a walkthrough but can be more disruptive to operations since tasks are actually completed.
  • Parallel Test: Parallel tests perform normal business operations at an alternate as well as the primary site. This ensures that the alternate site can complete its duties while minimizing the potential impact on normal operations.
  • Read-through/Tabletop: A read-through or tabletop exercise involves reading through and role-playing the disaster response plan. This is the cheapest, least disruptive, and least realistic form of testing.

questions.question: Which of the following correctly orders the phases of the Deming cycle?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Plan->Do->Check->Act

The Deming cycle is an iterative process for designing and implementing security controls. Its phases are in the following order:

  • Plan: Plan the control implementation
  • Do: Implement the controls
  • Check: Test whether the controls are effective
  • Act: Close any security gaps

The other answer options are in the incorrect order.

questions.question: Which of the following protocols operates at the LOWEST OSI layer?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: IP

IP operates at OSI Layer 3, while UDP and TCP are Layer 4 protocols, and HTTP is a Layer 7 protocol.

questions.question: Which of the following types of security plans provides the MOST detail about how something is to be accomplished?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Operational

Operational plans have an extremely short duration. They provide in-depth detail on how the organization will accomplish tasks to support their strategic or tactical plans.

Strategic plans are the longest type of security management plan. It describes overall security goals and can be viable for up to five years.

Tactical plans are the next longest and describe how particular goals can be accomplished. They're usually good for about a year.

Contingency plans are not one of the three types of security management plans.

questions.question: An organization has implemented N+1 UPS so that it can perform online maintenance. This corresponds to which Uptime Institute Redundancy Tier?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: 3

The Uptime Institute defines four redundancy tiers. The third one is N+1 UPS.

In order, the redundancy tiers are as follows:

  1. No redundancy
  2. N uninterruptible power supplies UPS
  3. N+1 UPS
  4. 2N UPS

questions.question: Which of the following threat models is named for the different types of threats that it looks for?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: STRIDE

STRIDE — Spoofing, Tampering, Repudiation, Information disclosure, Denial of service, and Elevation of privilege — is a Microsoft-developed threat modeling framework named for these six types of threats that an attacker may pose to the organization.

DREAD classifies threats based on the Damage, Reproducibility, Exploitability, Affected users, and Discoverability of a threat.

PASTA — Process of Attack Simulation and Threat Analysis — is a seven-step threat modeling framework that considers both risks and the importance of various corporate assets.

VAST — Visual, Agile, and Simple Threat — is a threat modeling framework customized for Agile environments.

questions.question: An organization wants to protect a unique process that it has developed and wants to license it to other companies. Which of the following IP protections makes the MOST sense?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Patent

Intellectual Property (IP) can be protected in four different ways:

  • Patent: Patents protect inventions against being copied. The subject of a patent must be new, useful, and non-obvious.
  • Trade secrets: Trade secrets are IP that must be kept secret to be protected. Often, this is accomplished by having employees sign NDAs.
  • Copyright: A copyright protects original works against unauthorized distribution, reproduction, and display. Copyrights can cover various things, including text, video, music, and more.
  • Trademark: A trademark protects a word, phrase, image, etc. that is a unique part of a corporate brand.

questions.question: Which of the following types of cabling is MOST susceptible to EMI?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: UTP

Unshielded Twisted Pair (UTP) cabling is the most susceptible to ElectroMagnetic Interference (EMI). 

Coaxial and Shielded Twisted Pair (STP) cabling have shielding against EMI, while fiber-optic cables use light rather than electrons to carry data.

questions.question: Which of the following types of software testing can be applied EARLIEST in the SDLC?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: SAST

Organizations can use various forms of testing to identify flaws in application code, including:

  • Static Application Security Testing (SAST): SAST often inspects the source code of the application to identify common flaws in the code. It can be applied early in the SDLC because it doesn’t require a completed, runnable application.
  • Dynamic Application Security Testing (DAST): DAST analyzes a running application for vulnerabilities by providing it with inputs and monitoring their results. DAST can use synthetic inputs, which are scripted interactions with certain expected results, and benchmarks, which evaluate the system against performance, effectiveness, and other metrics.
  • Interactive Application Security Testing (IAST): IAST combines internal visibility into an application with dynamic testing to enhance vulnerability detection.
  • Software Composition Analysis (SCA): SCA identifies vulnerabilities inherited from third-party libraries and dependencies, protecting against supply chain vulnerabilities.

questions.question: An organization is trying to build interest in its cybersecurity training program by creating prizing and recognizing winners on social media. This is an example of which of the following techniques?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Gamification

Gamification tries to build interest in security training by integrating rewards or penalties, making it more of a game-like experience.

A security champions program provides acknowledgement and support of people who take a role advocating for security and educating their colleagues within a team.

Social engineering is the practice of using manipulation or deception to trick a target into doing what an attacker wants. Phishing is a form of social engineering.

questions.question: When an employee logs onto a corporate system, they are presented with a warning banner stating that all activities on the system are monitored. This is an example of which of the following types of security controls?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Deterrent

The main types of security controls include the following:

  • Deterrent: Deterrent controls attempt to discourage an incident from occurring. Corporate policies, warning banners, and security cameras are examples of deterrent controls.
  • Preventive: Preventive controls are designed to stop an incident from happening. Fences, locks, and access controls are examples of preventive controls.
  • Compensating: Compensating controls are used as a replacement when the preferred control is unusable. For example, a company renting an office in a building may put locks on the doors when it can't build a fence.
  • Corrective: Corrective controls fix issues after a security incident. Antimalware that removes an infection or an auto-close arm on a door are examples of corrective controls.
  • Detective: Detective controls help to identify that an incident is occurring. CCTV, audit trails, and honeypots are examples of detective controls.
  • Recovery: Recovery controls restore normal operations after an incident to a greater extent than corrective ones. Backups and server clusters are examples of recovery controls.

questions.question: The Simple Security Rule in the Bell-Padula model prevents which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Reading at higher classification level

The Bell-Padula model is designed to protect confidentiality. Its three principles are as follows:

  • Simple Security Rule: Prevents reading data at a higher classification level.
  • *(star)-Property Rule: Prevents writing data to a lower classification level.
  • Discretionary Security Property/Strong Star Property Rule: A user with read and write access can only perform those actions at the same classification level.

questions.question: An organization is developing its five-year plan for cybersecurity. Which of the following types of plans is it creating?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Strategic

Strategic plans are the longest type of security management plan. It describes overall security goals and can be viable for up to five years.

Tactical plans are the next longest and describe how particular goals can be accomplished. They're usually good for about a year.

Operational plans have an extremely short duration. They provide in-depth detail on how the organization will accomplish tasks to support their strategic or tactical plans.

Contingency plans are not one of the three types of security management plans.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT one of the main parts of configuration management?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Access Management

Configuration management is about ensuring that devices are set up securely, while access management is about controlling who can use those devices.

Configuration management helps to ensure that devices are deployed and maintained in a secure state. The main parts of configuration management include:

  • Provisioning: Provisioning is the process of setting up a device, including installing the OS and apps and setting configuration settings. During the provisioning process, the device should be hardened, setting configuration settings to secure options and disabling unnecessary applications, ports, and services.
  • Baselining: Baselining defines a normal state for a device. Deviations from this baseline may introduce vulnerabilities into the system. Often, organizations use images for baselining, which allows them to install the image on a device and have it immediately be in a secure, approved state.
  • Automation: Administrators can also use automation to monitor and manage system configurations at scale. Automation can be used to set up a system, monitor systems for deviations from the baseline, and apply changes across the enterprise network.

questions.question: Which of the following roles defines the rules for data collection and processing?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Data controller

A data controller is responsible for defining how different types of data are collected and processed. Data controllers are often senior management.

A data owner is ultimately responsible for data and controls its classification, labeling, and disclosure. This is often the CEO or other senior management.

A data processor performs the actual processing of data, a role delegated to them by the data controller. Data processors are employees within the department who use the collected data.

A data custodian handles day-to-day protection and management of data, a role delegated to them by the data owner. Data custodians are usually within the IT/security department

questions.question: For which of the following types of software is the threat of malicious functionality hidden in the code the GREATEST?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Open source

Companies can acquire software from various sources, including:

  • Open Source Software (OSS): OSS is made freely available for anyone to use and includes access to the source code of the application. OSS often assumes that vulnerabilities will be detected because there are many eyes on it. Also, there is the risk that vulnerable or malicious code may be inserted into the project.
  • Commercial-off-the-shelf (COTS): COTS software like Microsoft Word is purchased by the organization to run on its own infrastructure. COTS vulnerabilities are often well-known, and a lack of access to source code makes vulnerabilities difficult to detect.
  • Third Party: Third-party software is developed by an external organization under contract. The development process may be managed by SLAs, and the company may or may not have access to source code.
  • Cloud Services: Cloud services like Software as a Service (SaaS), Infrastructure as a Service (IaaS), and Platform as a Service (PaaS) have varying breakdowns of responsibility between the cloud customer and provider. In SaaS, the organization uses an application created and managed by the cloud provider.

questions.question: Which of the following solutions is designed to improve application portability by enabling it to run across different computing environments?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Containerization

Containerization enhances application portability by packaging an application along with its dependencies into a self-contained environment called a container. This allows applications to be deployed consistently across different computing environments, such as on-premises servers, cloud platforms, and hybrid infrastructures. However, containers are not completely OS-agnostic—they rely on the underlying OS kernel. A Linux-based container will not natively run on a Windows host without a compatibility layer, such as Windows Subsystem for Linux (WSL) or a hypervisor-based solution.

Microservices break an application into different functional parts, which communicate via Application Programming Interfaces (APIs). These tend to be easier to deploy and scale than traditional applications but are harder to monitor. While microservices improve scalability and modularity, they do not inherently enhance portability across different environments.

Serverless architectures allow applications to run in an environment totally managed by the service provider. This relieves the developer of the responsibility of managing compute, storage, networking, etc.

Embedded systems are designed for specialized hardware and specific tasks, making them highly dependent on the underlying hardware and operating system rather than being portable.

questions.question: Which of the following classifications is commonly used for PII and PHI?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Private

Private organizations can use various means of classifying their data, but some commonly used labels include:

  • Private: Next-highest level of classified data and shouldn’t be shared outside of the organization and could cause significant damage if exposed. PII and PHI may be classified as private data.
  • Confidential or Proprietary: Highest level of classified data that could cause exceptional damage to the organization if exposed. An organization’s IP or secret cause could be considered proprietary data.
  • Sensitive: Data that could cause damage to the organization if made public. The organization’s network layout and the devices it uses may be sensitive data.
  • Public: Data that is intended to be openly disclosed. This includes the contents of websites, social media, brochures, etc.

questions.question: An organization is implementing fire suppression systems in its server room. Which of the following U.S. Classes of fire suppression systems should be installed?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Class C

Fire suppression systems are rated for the type of fire that they can put out. A Class C system is designed to address electrical fires.

Class A systems are for paper, wood, etc.

Class B systems are for liquid fires.

Class D systems are for metal fires.

questions.question: An organization is most concerned about legitimate users not having access to corporate resources. Which of the following error rates should the company be trying to MINIMIZE in its biometric authentication system?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: FRR

Biometric authentication systems can produce various types of errors, including:

  • False Negatives: False rejections or Type 1 errors are when a system fails to authenticate a legitimate user. The ratio of false rejections to valid authentications is the False Rejection Rate (FRR).
  • False Positives: False acceptances or Type 2 errors are when a system incorrectly authenticates an unauthorized user. The False Acceptance Rate (FAR) is calculated as the ratio of false acceptances to valid authentications.

The Crossover Error Rate (CER) or Equal Error Rate (ERR) is when the FRR equals the FAR.

questions.question: Which of the following fulfills a catch-all role if no specific guidance is provided?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Guidelines

Guidelines provide recommendations about how to do something if no specific standard exists.

Procedures are step-by-step descriptions of how a member of the organization should achieve a security goal.

A security policy is a high-level description of an organization's security requirements.

Standards define required activities that are designed to help an organization fulfill its policy goals.

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of an east-west traffic flow?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Inter-app communications in a microservices architecture

East-west traffic occurs within a datacenter or cloud environment and would include inter-app communications in a microservices architecture. 

Web browsing, email traffic, and third-party APIs all involve traffic entering/leaving the data center (north/south).

questions.question: An organization is seeking compliance with a data protection law. Which of the following is it MOST likely to be required to undergo as part of this process?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Security audit

Security audits are performed by accredited, third-party auditors. They are designed to prove to regulators or customers that the organization’s security controls meet the requirements of a particular regulation or standard.

Security tests validate that a security control is doing its job. They range from fully-automated scans to manual penetration testing.

Security assessments involve a trained professional performing a comprehensive review of the environment under test. It is a more thorough assessment of the security of the threat environment.

Security evaluation doesn't have a particular meaning in the CISSP exam.

questions.question: An organization believes that an incident has occurred that might require a reprimand from HR. Which of the following types of investigations is MOST likely to occur?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Administrative

Security investigations fall into one of four types:

  • Administrative: Administrative investigations are internal affairs and may be intended to troubleshoot a problem or address an HR issue. Operational (troubleshooting) investigations have the loosest standards, while ones conducted for HR purposes may have a higher requirement for proof.
  • Criminal: Criminal investigations involve law enforcement, must follow strict evidence collection requirements, and are intended to prove a crime "beyond a reasonable doubt."
  • Civil Investigations: Civil investigations do not involve law enforcement and may be conducted internally or with external consultants. They are conducted to collect evidence to bring charges in civil court. They have less stringent evidence standards than criminal investigations because they only have to prove that the "preponderance of the evidence" supports the case.
  • Regulatory: Regulatory investigations are conducted by regulators to prove non-compliance with laws and standards. Their requirements depend on the type of case to be brought against a non-compliant company.

questions.question: An organization is developing its Business Continuity Plan (BCP) and specifying how long a system can be unavailable without causing major harm to the business. Which of the following are they calculating?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: MTD

Maximum Tolerable Downtime (MTD) specifies the maximum amount of time that a system can be down due to an incident without causing significant harm to the business.

Recovery Time Objective (RTO) is the maximum amount of time it should take to restore a system after an outage. RTO should be less than MTD.

Recovery Point Objective (RPO) is the maximum acceptable amount of data loss due to an outage. Backups should be created more frequently than this.

A Business Impact Analysis (BIA) is used to calculate these other values.

questions.question: Which of the following types of cryptographic algorithms is BEST suited to encrypting data at rest?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Symmetric

Symmetric cryptographic algorithms are best suited to encrypting data at rest because they are more efficient than other algorithms, and the key can be securely stored on the device (no need for key sharing).

questions.question: Which of the following types of security testing is the LEAST likely to be fully automated?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Penetration test

Security testing comes in a variety of different forms. Some of the main types include:

  • Penetration Testing: Penetration testing includes vulnerability assessments but also attempts to exploit the vulnerabilities that they discover. Additionally, they involve more manual testing than a fully-automated vulnerability scan.
  • Vulnerability Assessments: Vulnerability assessments use automated tools to identify vulnerabilities within an organization’s systems, including networks, web applications, and databases. Typically these check an application against the list of Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures (CVEs) to identify known issues. These vulnerabilities are scored using the Common Vulnerability Scoring System (CVSS), which helps in identifying how severe the vulnerability is.
  • Breach and Attack Simulations (BAS): BAS platforms are designed to perform automated penetration testing. They introduce indicators of compromise (IoCs) into the system — malicious files, C2 traffic, etc. — and check if the corporate security controls identify it.
  • Compliance Checks: Compliance checks verify that an organization implements the security controls required by applicable regulations and that they are functional. These tests can also be automated.

questions.question: Which of the following solutions will identify and block a distribute Denial-of-Service (DDoS) attack?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: IPS

An Intrusion Detection System (IDS) identifies signs of a potential attack – such as a Denial of Service (DoS) attack – and alerts security personnel. An Intrusion Prevention System (IPS) goes a step further and blocks the attempted attack.

A honeypot is a computer designed to look like a tempting target to lure attackers into attacking it instead of real corporate systems. This both wastes the attacker’s time and enables the organization to observe their tools and techniques. A honeynet is a network of honeypots.

Antimalware is software installed on an endpoint that can identify, block, and potentially eradicate an infection on that system.

questions.question: Which of the following is LEAST related to the others?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Quality of Service

Quality of Service (QoS) deals with prioritizing traffic when bandwidth is limited.

Clustering is a means of achieving high availability and fault tolerance, which measure a system's resiliency to component failures.

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of an INTANGIBLE asset?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Intellectual property

An organization's intangible assets include intellectual property (unique processes, patents, etc.), reputation, etc.

Tangible assets include an organization’s hardware (computer and router) and software (application).

questions.question: Which of the following principles is LEAST likely to be applicable during the Requirements stage of the Software Design LifeCycle (SDLC)?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Shared responsibility

Shared responsibility deals with the fact that a company may share responsibility for its security with a third party.

The principles of secure defaults, privacy by design, and failing securely may need to be implemented via explicit requirements for a piece of software.

questions.question: An organization is using a testing methodology that crafts inputs to try edge cases and find potential flaws in the application. Which of the following does this BEST describe?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Fuzz Testing

Application vulnerabilities are a common target for cybercriminals. Some ways to manage the number of vulnerabilities that reach production include:

  • Fuzz Testing: Fuzzing sends various inputs to an application to try to identify failure cases. These inputs may be randomly generated or intelligently selected based on a model of the system to maximize the probability of finding an issue.
  • Code Review: Code review involves another developer reviewing code for potential issues. Often, this is accomplished by requiring a review before code is incorporated into a code repository.
  • Interface Testing: Interface testing verifies that the different components of a system will work properly when linked together. The four types of interfaces to test include APIs, User Interfaces (UIs), network interfaces, and physical interfaces.
  • Misuse Case Testing: Misuse or abuse case testing identifies ways in which a user could misuse an application and tests its responses to these malicious inputs.

questions.question: Which of the following is focused SOLELY on threat prevention?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Blocklist

A blacklist/blocklist prevents threats by blocking certain types of applications or network traffic. 

An Intrusion Detection System (IDS) only provides threat detection, and honeypots and sandboxing could provide both detection and prevention.

questions.question: Which of the following is MOST related to Data Loss Prevention (DLP)?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Egress monitoring

Egress monitoring looks for attempted exfiltration of corporate data and is part of Data Loss Prevention (DLP)

Continuous monitoring is intended to ensure that an organization's security controls are effective between audits.

Threat hunting searches for signs of an intruder resident within an organization's network.

User and Entity Behavioral Analytics (UEBA) looks for anomalous user actions that could be indicative of a compromised account or malicious activity.

questions.question: Which of the of the following domains of the Software Assurance Maturity Model (SAMM) includes Architecture Assessment and Requirements-Driven Testing?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Verification

Verification includes Architecture Assessment, Requirements-Driven Testing, and Security Testing.

The Software Assurance Maturity Model (SAMM) was developed by the Open Web Application Security Project (OWASP) and includes five domains:

  • Verification: Architecture Assessment, Requirements-Driven Testing, and Security Testing
  • Governance: Strategy and Metrics, Policy and Compliance, and Education and Guidance
  • Operations: Incident Management, Environment Management, and Operational Management
  • Implementation: Secure Build, Secure Deployment, and Defect Management
  • Design: Threat Assessment, Security Requirements, and Security Architecture

questions.question: Which of the following uses test cases with known results to ensure that the system works properly?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Synthetic inputs

Code testing is designed to identify software vulnerabilities and can be applied at different stages of the Software Development LifeCycle (SDLC). Some forms of code testing include:

  • Dynamic Application Security Testing (DAST): DAST analyzes a running application for vulnerabilities by providing it with inputs and monitoring their results. DAST can use synthetic inputs, which are scripted interactions with certain expected results, and benchmarks, which evaluate the system against performance, effectiveness, and other metrics.
  • Fuzz Testing: Fuzzing sends various inputs to an application to try to identify failure cases. These inputs may be randomly generated or intelligently selected based on a model of the system to maximize the probability of finding an issue.
  • Interface Testing: Interface testing verifies that the different components of a system will work properly when linked together. The four types of interfaces to test include APIs, User Interfaces (UIs), network interfaces, and physical interfaces.
  • Misuse Case Testing: Misuse or abuse case testing identifies ways in which a user could misuse an application and tests its responses to these malicious inputs.

questions.question: Which of the following solutions is a software solution designed to protect one application's data from being read by another?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Memory protection

Memory protection allocates distinct memory spaces to each running application and prevents them from reading each other's memory.

A Trusted Platform Module (TPM) is a built-in chip on a motherboard used to store cryptographic keys.

TPMs are a type of Hardware Security Module (HSM), which includes both built-in and removable devices.

Encryption/decryption protect data confidentiality by scrambling data in a way that makes it unrecoverable without the right private key.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT an example of an Agile programming methodology?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Waterfall

Developers can use various methodologies to organize software development. Some of the most common include:

  • Waterfall: Waterfall moves sequentially through the phases of the SDLC without backtracking or iteration. This approach ensures that each stage is fully completed before the next but is rigid and inflexible.
  • Agile: Agile is a high-level set of principles adopted by many development methodologies, such as Extreme Programming (XP), Test-Driven Development (TDD), and Scrum. Agile is built around sprints, which make frequent, small changes to software rather than a single, monolithic development cycle.
  • DevOps: DevOps methodologies use automation to streamline and expedite software development, testing, and deployment. By integrating development, QA, and ops teams and using automation, DevOps enables rapid release cycles.
  • DevSecOps: DevSecOps integrates security more fully into DevOps processes and the SDLC. DevSecOps explicitly defines security requirements for software and builds security testing into automated CI/CD pipelines.

questions.question: Which of the following parts of configuration management might involve the creation of a gold image?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Baselining

Configuration management helps to ensure that devices are deployed and maintained in a secure state. Baselining defines a normal state for a device. Organizations use images for baselining, which allows them to install the image on a device. A "gold image" is properly configured and contains all required applications, etc.

The main parts of configuration management include:

  • Provisioning: Provisioning is the process of setting up a device, including installing the OS and apps and setting configuration settings. During the provisioning process, the device should be hardened, setting configuration settings to secure options and disabling unnecessary applications, ports, and services.
  • Baselining: Baselining defines a normal state for a device. Deviations from this baseline may introduce vulnerabilities into the system. Often, organizations use images for baselining, which allows them to install the image on a device and have it immediately be in a secure, approved state.
  • Automation: Administrators can also use automation to monitor and manage system configurations at scale. Automation can be used to set up a system, monitor systems for deviations from the baseline, and apply changes across the enterprise network.

Deprovisioning isn't a core part of configuration management.

questions.question: Which of the following types of security testing relies the MOST on resources such as the CVE list?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Vulnerability assessments

Security testing comes in a variety of different forms. Some of the main types include:

  • Vulnerability Assessments: Vulnerability assessments use automated tools to identify vulnerabilities within an organization’s systems, including networks, web applications, and databases. Typically these check an application against the list of Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures (CVEs) to identify known issues. These vulnerabilities are scored using the Common Vulnerability Scoring System (CVSS), which helps in identifying how severe the vulnerability is.
  • Penetration Testing: Penetration testing includes vulnerability assessments but also attempts to exploit the vulnerabilities that they discover. Additionally, they involve more manual testing than a fully automated vulnerability scan.
  • Breach and Attack Simulations (BAS): BAS platforms are designed to perform automated penetration testing. They introduce Indicators of Compromise (IoCs) into the system – malicious files, C2 traffic, etc. – and check if the corporate security controls identify it.
  • Compliance Checks: Compliance checks verify that an organization implements the security controls required by applicable regulations and that they are functional.

questions.question: In which of the following types of audits does an organization have the LEAST control over the results?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Third-party

Audits come in three types:

  • Third-Party: Third-party audits are controlled and conducted by third parties. A regulator may select or accredit the auditor and can use the results to determine compliance.
  • Internal: Internal audits are performed by the organization’s own staff and for its purposes. For example, they may be intended to prove that the company is meeting its security goals.
  • External: External audits are performed by an external organization. Often, they are paid for by the organization, which has a certain level of control over it. However, they are considered more trustworthy than an internal audit since the external auditor is independent of the company under test.

Hybrid is not a type of security audit.

questions.question: Which of the following refers to solutions that might prioritize certain types of network traffic over others?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Quality of Service

Quality of Service (QoS) manages network traffic so that more important traffic is given priority if bandwidth is limited.

Fault tolerance means that a system can continue to function despite the loss or fault of certain components. Precise definitions of fault tolerance tiers are defined by the Uptime Institute.

High availability uses load balancing and clusters to ensure that services remain available even if one system fails.

questions.question: Which of the following values should be used to set the frequency at which an organization performs backups?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: RPO

Recovery Point Objective (RPO) is the maximum acceptable amount of data loss due to an outage. Backups should be created more frequently than this.

Maximum Tolerable Downtime (MTD) specifies the maximum amount of time that a system can be down due to an incident without causing significant harm to the business.

Recovery Time Objective (RTO) is the maximum amount of time it should take to restore a system after an outage. RTO should be less than MTD.

A Business Impact Analysis (BIA) is used to calculate these other values.

questions.question: Which of the following classification levels is used for the data that poses the MOST potential risk to the business?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Confidential

Private organizations can use various means of classifying their data. 

Confidential or proprietary is the highest level of classified data that could cause exceptional damage to the organization if exposed. An organization’s IP or secret cause could be considered proprietary data.

Private is the next-highest level of classified data and shouldn’t be shared outside of the organization and could cause significant damage if exposed. PII and PHI may be classified as private data.

Sensitive data is data that could cause damage to the organization if made public. The organization’s network layout and the devices it uses may be sensitive data.

Public data is data that is intended to be openly disclosed. This includes the contents of websites, social media, brochures, etc.

questions.question: Which of the following types of disaster plan testing offers the LEAST realistic assessment of the plan's effectiveness?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Walkthrough

In a walkthrough, the team physically performs the actions described in the plan (unless they would disrupt operations). 

Testing disaster response plans is essential to ensure that they are effective and nothing is missed. Testing can be performed in various ways, including:

  • Walkthrough: In a walkthrough, the team physically performs the actions described in the plan (unless they would disrupt operations). This can build familiarity and help identify parts of the plan that are impossible or require additional resources.
  • Simulation: In a simulation like a fire drill, the team is given a scenario and tasked with responding to it. This is more realistic than a walkthrough but can be more disruptive to operations since tasks are actually completed.
  • Parallel Test: Parallel tests perform normal business operations at an alternate as well as the primary site. This ensures that the alternate site can complete its duties while minimizing the potential impact on normal operations.
  • Full-Interruption Test: A full-interruption test actually switches operations over from the primary to the recovery site. This is more disruptive and risky than a parallel test but actually verifies that the organization’s failover processes work.
  • Read-through/Tabletop: A read-through or tabletop exercise involves reading through and role-playing the disaster response plan. This is the cheapest, least disruptive, and least realistic form of testing.

questions.question: An organization has implemented context-aware authentication to improve security. This typically uses which of the following types of authentication factors?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Somewhere you are

Context-aware authentication uses location, time, device information, and other contextual data to authenticate a user. Location is an example of a somewhere you are factor.

Something you know authentication includes passwords, PINs, etc.

Something you have authentication includes smartcards, smartphones, and hardware tokens.

Something you are authentication includes fingerprints, facial recognition, etc.

questions.question: Which of the following types of cryptoanalytic attacks attempts to force a situation to occur where sensitive information is leaked?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Fault injection

In a fault injection attack, the attacker causes a fault to occur in a device (using power, temperature, etc.) to cause it to leak information.

In a side-channel attack (which includes timing attacks), the attacker observes the time taken, power consumption, or other factors during cryptographic operations that may leak sensitive data.

A brute force attack involves guessing every possible private key until the correct one is found.

questions.question: Which of the following describes REQUIRED activities necessary for an organization to achieve its security goals?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Standards

Standards define required activities that are designed to help an organization fulfill its policy goals.

Procedures are step-by-step descriptions of how a member of the organization should achieve a security goal.

A security policy is a high-level description of an organization's security requirements.

Guidelines provide recommendations about how to do something if no specific standard exists.

questions.question: Which of the following forms of removing sensitive data is the MOST effective in cloud environments?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Cryptoshredding

Data remanence refers to information that remains after a disk, USB drive, etc. has been erased. Simply deleting a file isn’t enough since additional information will be left behind. Some methods of securely deleting data include:

  • Cryptoshredding: Cryptoshredding or cryptographic erasure destroys the cryptographic keys used to protect encrypted data. This runs the risk that the encryption algorithm may be broken in the future or a backup key might be discovered. However, it is often the only available option in cloud environments.
  • Erasing: Erasing uses the built-in delete functionality on a computer to remove pointers to the data. However, the actual data remains on disk until it is overwritten by something else.
  • Degaussing: Degaussing uses a magnetic field to wipe data from magnetic tapes and Hard Disk Drives (HDDs). It doesn’t work on optical disks or flash storage (including USBs, SSDs, and SD cards).
  • Destruction: Destruction physically damages the media to the point that it is impossible to retrieve data from it.

questions.question: An organization operating in the USA plans to process customer payment card data on an ecommerce site. Which of the following MUST it comply with?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: PCI DSS

The Payment Card Industry Data Security Standard (PCI DSS) is a regulation protecting payment card data. Any organization with access to this data must comply with PCI DSS.

GDPR is a data privacy law that only applies to EU citizens. 

The NIST CSF and ISO 27001 are optional cybersecurity frameworks.

questions.question: Which of the following security management processes is MOST targeted at identifying cybersecurity incidents?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Log reviews

Security management processes should include the following:

  • Log Reviews: Log reviews can be used to identify anomalous behavior by an application or potential security incidents. For example, reviewing access logs can help to identify anomalous access attempts or abuse of legitimate privileges.
  • Business Continuity and Disaster Recovery (BC/DR): BC/DR programs should include strategies for maintaining operations during an incident (BC) and restoring normal operations after the incident (DR). Backups, redundant systems, and other controls are key parts of BC/DR programs, and their effectiveness should be regularly reviewed.
  • Training and Awareness: Cybersecurity awareness training ensures that employees are aware of potential security threats and best practices. Training should be performed regularly and be tailored to a user’s role and the threats that they are most likely to face.
  • Key Performance and Risk Indicators: Tracking metrics is essential to measuring the maturity of the organization’s security program and progress over time. An organization may track the number of unpatched vulnerabilities, average time to patch, repeated audit findings, and other metrics.

questions.question: At which stage of the Capability Maturity Model Integration (CMMI) does the organization adopt a culture of continuous improvement?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Optimizing

The Capability Maturity Model Integration (CMMI) was developed by the U.S. Department of Defense and Carnegie Mellon University’s Software Engineering Institute (SEI). Optimizing is the fifth stage.

CMMI defines five maturity stages in the following order:

  1. Initial: Processes are ad hoc, reactive, and unpredictable.
  2. Managed: Processes are still largely reactive but are characterized or documented for an individual project.
  3. Defined: Proactive processes are defined and documented at the organizational level rather than the project level.
  4. Quantitatively Managed: The organization tracks quantitative metrics regarding processes.
  5. Optimizing: The organization has a culture of continuous improvement where processes are documented, measured, and improved through lessons learned.

questions.question: An organization has purchased a service that occasionally plants malware on its systems to test its incident detection processes. Which of the following does this BEST describe?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Breach and Attack Simulations

Security testing comes in a variety of different forms. Some of the main types include:

  • Breach and Attack Simulations (BAS): BAS platforms are designed to perform automated penetration testing. They introduce Indicators of Compromise (IoCs) into the system – malicious files, C2 traffic, etc. – and check if the corporate security controls identify it.
  • Vulnerability Assessments: Vulnerability assessments use automated tools to identify vulnerabilities within an organization’s systems, including networks, web applications, and databases. Typically these check an application against the list of Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures (CVEs) to identify known issues. These vulnerabilities are scored using the Common Vulnerability Scoring System (CVSS), which helps in identifying how severe the vulnerability is.
  • Penetration Testing: Penetration testing includes vulnerability assessments but also attempts to exploit the vulnerabilities that they discover. Additionally, they involve more manual testing than a fully automated vulnerability scan.
  • Compliance Checks: Compliance checks verify that an organization implements the security controls required by applicable regulations and that they are functional.

questions.question: During which stage of the information system lifecycle will the organization ensure that the system as a whole works by combining the individual pieces?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Integration

The Integration stage is when the development team verifies that all the various components of the system work properly together.

The Architectural Design stage is when a design for the system is created. 

Implementation is when it is coded, and Verification and Validation is when it is tested to ensure it meets requirements.

questions.question: Which of the following types of recovery sites is MOST likely to be used by a disaster response group?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Mobile

Some disaster response groups use mobile sites, which build a server room in a shipping container or vehicle that can be easily transported to wherever it is needed.

Recovery sites can be classified based on the level of infrastructure that they provide and the amount of work needed to bring them online. The main types include:

  • Cold: A cold site provides a location and potentially infrastructure (power, Internet, etc.) but no devices. It is the cheapest site to maintain but the slowest and most expensive to bring online.
  • Warm: A warm site has more equipment than a cold site, potentially including some devices but needing others to be added when needed.
  • Hot: A hot site is an exact copy of the primary site with the same devices and the same data (potentially with some lag). It’s the most expensive type of site to maintain but the fastest to use.

questions.question: Which of the following types of security testing may include the use of synthetic inputs and known benchmarks?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: DAST

Organizations can use various forms of testing to identify flaws in application code, including:

  • Dynamic Application Security Testing (DAST): DAST analyzes a running application for vulnerabilities by providing it with inputs and monitoring their results. DAST can use synthetic inputs, which are scripted interactions with certain expected results, and benchmarks, which evaluate the system against performance, effectiveness, and other metrics.
  • Static Application Security Testing (SAST): SAST often inspects the source code of the application to identify common flaws in the code. It can be applied early in the SDLC because it doesn’t require a completed, runnable application.
  • Interactive Application Security Testing (IAST): IAST combines internal visibility into an application with dynamic testing to enhance vulnerability detection.
  • Software Composition Analysis (SCA): SCA identifies vulnerabilities inherited from third-party libraries and dependencies, protecting against supply chain vulnerabilities.

questions.question: A user entering their username into a login page is intended to provide which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Identification

Identification is when a user claims a particular identity, kicking off the process of authentication and authorization. Usernames identify, passwords authenticate.

The AAA model of access control includes:

  • Authentication: Verifying the identity of a user, device, application, etc.
  • Authorization: Validating that an entity has the right to make a particular request.
  • Accounting: Maintaining an audit trail of activities performed by users.

questions.question: Trade secrets are a means of protecting which of the following types of data?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Proprietary

Proprietary data includes an organization’s Intellectual Property (IP) and similar information that can help it compete in the marketplace. Trade secrets are one way of protecting proprietary data.

Personally Identifiable Information (PII) can be used to uniquely identify someone. Examples include names, social security numbers, date of birth, etc.

Protected Health Information (PHI) is healthcare data that is collected by healthcare providers and their business associates. It is protected under the Health Insurance Portability and Accessibility Act (HIPAA).

Digital Rights Management (DRM) protects copyrighted works against piracy. This can be accomplished by issuing a license, automatically expiring content, or performing persistent authentication whenever the work is used.

questions.question: Which of the following VPN protocols operates at OSI Layer 3?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: IPsec

IPsec is a VPN protocol that operates at Layer 3 of the OSI model. 

The Point-to-Point Tunneling Protocol (PPTP) and Layer 2 Tunneling Protocol (L2TP) operate at OSI Layer 2. 

Transport Layer Security (TLS) can be used as a VPN and operates at Layer 4 (Transport Layer).
